intro: Corydalis corymbosa, commonly known as the clustered corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Asia. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that bloom in shades of pink, purple, and white. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and features slender, hairy stems with alternate, lance-shaped leaves. Its root system consists of tubers, which are often used in traditional medicine. Corydalis corymbosa thrives in woodland and meadow habitats, preferring cool, moist conditions with partial shade.
